@KtShy Often the turning points in people's careers come when people take a chance on them. We need more of that for more people, for sure!

(In short I'm a bit of a coward, haha. Shhh.)
It's not that I'm afraid of debate, it's just so personal to so many of them, and harder when it's family/people I care about getting upset.
Anyway, sorry for the Twitter rant. Can't really talk about it elsewhere, as too many family members might see and take offence.
@KtShy @FaithErinHicks The lack of women in leadership roles means a lack of women getting recognized/boosted for similar reasons.
@KtShy @FaithErinHicks I was moved by the "You remind me of young me" part. How many times has that helped men in their careers?
I just hope that we also consider the nuances of the issue: If we MUST use oil, there are worse choices than Canadian oil.
That being said:I support any moves towards a greener economy less reliant on fossil fuels and any legislation that protects the environment
(And yes, they're well educated, and well travelled. They aren't prairie hicks with no perspective living in a bubble.)
I don't think it has to be that way, but I'm also not qualified or educated enough to suggest real changes. Just asking for compassion.
I'm regularly frustrated listening to both sides of these arguments. Both are so entrenched and personal. It's "Our Home" vs. "Our Planet".
I don't know where I'm going with this. This stuff is all so complicated, and it's not helpful to paint these things with a broad brush.
They are real people living in a vibrant, close-knit community they've worked hard to create. Many have grown up there, know no other home.
And the people who live in Fort Mac and rely on the plants aren't selfish money-grabbers looking for quick cash and early retirement.
But it's also true that Canadian Oil is some of the cleanest and most environmentally conscious of any oil production in the world.
Oil, as a whole, is bad for our planet. Canada is complicit in being one of the larger oil producers in the world.
(Of course this is true of any debate. Things are rarely if ever black and white.)
…any defence of the oil sands as a vote for destroying the earth. It's hard to have meaningful conversations when there's no middle ground.
On the one hand, I have friends who see any criticism of the oil sands as a personal attack. On the other hand, I have friends who see…
I'm also angry at the lack of progress in the face of climate change, one of the biggest dangers I believe we'll face in the coming years.
I have dozens of friends and family who still live in Fort Mac, who work at the plants, and rely on the oil economy to keep them afloat.
It's tricky being in the middle of two often opposing sides: Alberta Oil Country (where I grew up) and Liberal/Progressive Vancouver.
